note.p: William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)

catDesc.term: Legislation. Confederate States of America. Congress

gloss.p: The Confederate States of America Congress was a legislative and provisional assembly formed on February 18, 1862, and disbanded on March 18, 1865. Its intent was to establish a new governing body for the states seceding from the United States and to support a war effort. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Legislation. Confederate States of America. Congress. Sequestration Act (1861)

gloss.p: Enacted on August 30, 1861, the Confederate States of America Congress Legislation Sequestration Act (1861) was passed in response to the United States Congress Confiscation Act, which allowed the federal government to seize property being used to aid the Confederate States, including enslaved persons. The Sequestration Act targeted personal and real property of those not belonging to the Confederate States of America, commanding those who had or found alien property to give said property to the Confederate States of America's government. ("Baker on Weitz, 'The Confederacy on Trial: The Piracy and Sequestration Cases of 1861," H-CivWar)

While the U.S. Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. U.S. Congress divides legislators into separate committees who write federal or national legislation, and a vast industry of lobbyists also help members write legislation on behalf of corporate and labor interests. Once written, the proposed legislation is introduced to both houses, and if the bill passes both chambers by a majority vote, it is sent to the U.S. President for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and Congress can overcome the President's veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Legislation. United States. Congress. Confiscation Act, 1861

gloss.p: The United States Congress Confiscation Act of 1861, also known as the First Confiscation Act, was passed on August 5, 1861 and allowed for the confiscation of property, including land, buildings, livestock, and enslaved persons, used for the purpose of insurrection by the Confederate rebellion via court proceedings. This act created a legal mechanism for the emancipation of some enslaved people as well. As Federal forces not only foraged and pillaged their way across the South, the First Confiscation Act also empowered Union forces to seek judicial approval to temporarily confiscate enslaved people as property used to aid the Confederate war effort. In effect, those enslaved people taken by became "property" of the government of the United States due to the ambiguous wording of the law and authorized the government to use enslaved people as laborers for the Union army. This law was the first step by the United States government towards emancipation and was created as a way to undermine the Confederacy's ability to wage war physically and economically. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Legislation. United States. Congress. Confiscation Act, 1862

gloss.p: The United States Congress Confiscation Act of 1862, also known as the Second Confiscation Act, was passed on July 17, 1862, and allowed for the confiscation of property, including land, buildings, livestock, and enslaved persons, used for the purpose of insurrection by the Confederate rebellion via court proceedings. This act was introduced to address the shortcomings of the Confiscation Act of 1861 and allowed explicit freedom for enslaved people in conquered rebel territories or who self-emancipated to Northern territory, as well as prohibiting the return of emancipated enslaved people back to their enslavers, including in states in the Union where enslavement was still legal. This act introduced fines or punishments up to and including death for the act of treason. Significantly, the act created a legal mechanism for recruiting Black soldiers into the Union military and served as the legal basis for the Emancipation Proclamation. (Wikipedia; United States Senate)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A member of a group of people who together have the power to make laws." (Cambridge Dictionary)

The Congress of the Confederate States of America was established by Article 1 of the Confederate States Constitution on March 11, 1861 in Montgomery, Alabama. Operating at the national level of the Confederacy, it was the Legislative Branch of the Confederate States government responsible for making and amending laws. A bicameral body, the Confederate States Congress was divided into the upper house (Senate) and the lower house (House of Representatives). The Confederate States Congress concluded Its final session on March 18, 1865. (Avalon Project-Constitution of the Confederate States; March 11, 1861; Wikipedia)

Operating at the national level, the United States Congress was founded in 1789 as a part of the legislative branch of the nation's federal government. It is comprised of the Senate and the House of Representatives, both of whom are responsible for creating and passing bills and convene at the State's Capitol located in Washington, D.C. Members can be elected to serve repeatedly and must be at least twenty-five years of age for the House of Representatives and at least thirty for the Senate. They must also reside in the state in which they represent and have United States Citizenship for at least seven years for the House of Representatives or nine years for the Senate. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Legislature (originally called the "General Assembly") was established by Article 4 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890, and serves as the legislative branch of the state government. It is comprised of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Legislature is responsible for passing new statewide laws and making amendments to the Constitution. (Wikipedia)

div.p: I am a lawyer of more than thirty years' standing, have been Judge for some years, and was formerly a member of both houses of Congress from this State, and, now that the war is over, have a strong inclination to go South and practice my profession. Will there not be much litigation growing out of the Confiscation act of the U. S. Congress, as also out of the Seques-tration act of the late Confederate Congress and other matters connected with the war?
I should like to form a partnership with some able resident lawyer. Will you have the kindness to give me your advice and make suggestions on the subject?

John Pettit
wishes your advice about coming South to practice Law
